Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Isolated Hepatic Perfusion Versus Best Alternative Care for Uveal Melanoma Liver Metastases

Trial_Design.evidence: In this multicenter, phase III randomised controlled trial, 93 patients with untreated isolated liver metastases from uveal melanoma were enrolled between 2013 and 2021.

Participants.evidence: 93 patients with untreated isolated liver metastases from uveal melanoma

Intervention.evidence: Patients were randomised 1:1 to receive a one-time IHP treatment or BAC

Objective.evidence: This study assesses isolated hepatic perfusion (IHP) versus best alternative care (BAC) for overall survival (OS) and health-related quality of life (HRQOL).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary endpoint was the 24-month OS rate.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 93 patients with untreated isolated liver metastases from uveal melanoma were enrolled between 2013 and 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The intention-to-treat (ITT) analysis included 43 patients in the IHP group and 44 in the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 24-month OS rate was 46.5% in the IHP group versus 29.5% in the control group (P=0.12). Median OS was 21.7 months for IHP and 17.6 months for BAC (HR 0.64, 95% CI 0.37–1.10).

Harms.evidence: Severe adverse events occurred in 19.5% of IHP patients and 6.5% of BAC patients.
